intro: Plectritis macrocera var. mamillata, commonly known as the hairy plectritis, is a flowering plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, open habitats such as meadows and stream banks. Its hairy stems and leaves give it a distinctive appearance and help it retain moisture in its native environment.
